comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Wanamaker is properly spelled with only one "n." This is the roof of the Wanamaker store in New York City, where the balloon was tethered for several days while it was filled with hydrogen gas made on the spot by pouring sulphuric acid over iron filings. It was planned that the balloon would be launched and steered toward Philadelphia, but the pilot got lost in fog and landed in West Nyack instead. Here's the story from the New York Times, July 9, 1911: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9506E0D71431E233A... Another Bain/LOC photo of the Wanamaker balloon: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163757324/in/photostream/] And another: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2162950295/in/photostream/] Balloonist Leo Stevens in the basket of the Wanamaker balloon: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163708034/] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2162732173/]
